title: Capital Allocation Trends At Flowtech Fluidpower (LON:FLO) Aren't Ideal
description: If you're looking at a mature business that's past the growth phase, what are some of the underlying trends that pop...
content:
If you're looking at a mature business that's past the growth phase, what are some of the underlying trends that pop up? A business that's potentially in decline often shows two trends, a return on capital employed (ROCE) that's declining, and a base of capital employed that's also declining. This combination can tell you that not only is the company investing less, it's earning less on what it does invest. So after glancing at the trends within Flowtech Fluidpower (LON:FLO), we weren't too hopeful.

Trump has pledged to "unleash" American oil and gas and these 15 US stocks have developments that are poised to benefit.

For those who don't know, ROCE is a measure of a company's yearly pre-tax profit (its return), relative to the capital employed in the business. The formula for this calculation on Flowtech Fluidpower is:

Return on Capital Employed = Earnings Before Interest and Tax (EBIT) ÷ (Total Assets - Current Liabilities)

0.0052 = UK£330k ÷ (UK£86m - UK£23m) (Based on the trailing twelve months to December 2024).

Therefore, Flowtech Fluidpower has an ROCE of 0.5%. Ultimately, that's a low return and it under-performs the Trade Distributors industry average of 12%.

Above you can see how the current ROCE for Flowtech Fluidpower compares to its prior returns on capital, but there's only so much you can tell from the past. If you're interested, you can view the analysts predictions in our free analyst report for Flowtech Fluidpower .

What The Trend Of ROCE Can Tell Us

We are a bit anxious about the trends of ROCE at Flowtech Fluidpower. The company used to generate 8.2% on its capital five years ago but it has since fallen noticeably. In addition to that, Flowtech Fluidpower is now employing 37% less capital than it was five years ago. The combination of lower ROCE and less capital employed can indicate that a business is likely to be facing some competitive headwinds or seeing an erosion to its moat. If these underlying trends continue, we wouldn't be too optimistic going forward.

Our Take On Flowtech Fluidpower's ROCE

To see Flowtech Fluidpower reducing the capital employed in the business in tandem with diminishing returns, is concerning. It should come as no surprise then that the stock has fallen 13% over the last five years, so it looks like investors are recognizing these changes. Unless there is a shift to a more positive trajectory in these metrics, we would look elsewhere.
summary: The trend of capital allocation within Flowtech Fluidpower (LON:FLO), a mature business that is in decline can indicate a company investing less and earning less on what it invests. The company's return on capital employed (ROCE) is a measure of a company's yearly pre-tax profit relative to the capital employed in the business. The current ROCE is 0.5%, which is a low return and underperforms the Trade Distributors industry average of 12%. The company used to generate 8.2% on its capital five years ago, but has since fallen significantly. It is now employing 37% less capital than it was five years before. This could indicate a business facing competitive headwinds or an erosion of its moat.
shortSummary: The declining ROCE and reduced capital employed by Flowtech Fluidpower, despite improved investment, are concerning investor concerns and potential competitive headwinds.
